posts.name: John Fogarty
posts.cooked:
Hello,

I’ve been working with one of my students to setup pose estimation on our robot to eventually use for some grid alignment, but for now we are attempting to do the first step in getting a working pose estimator.

We have 2 limelight v3s mounted in a kind of “bug-eye” directions outward on two points of our robot. Their FOV slightly overlaps so that there can be vision of a tag straight in front of the robot on either side, which is somewhat redundant but still we thought it made sense. Each camera has it’s config set internally with their camera to robot based position. We roughly are only getting like 20fps on each camera. I’m not sure if the pipeline could be tuned better for more performance.

We tried to setup a basic system to update the pose using the periodic function of our vision subsystem… but what we see between the camera’s reported pose and the odometry pose doesn’t line up with the pose estimator.

Sometimes each camera and the odometry will line up pretty close X,Y positionally, but the pose estimator will show a pose way off to the left almost a half meter or more away. We set the vision standard deviation to have a really large theta value because of how our limelight mounting strategy works we know the cameras will never correctly report the right angle, but we can be reasonably sure that the Pidgeon 2 on our drive system will be correct.

We tried a large set of different vision std deviation values which are logged in the comments, but none seem to have the desired effect and the pose estimator continues to give bad positional data estimates.

It’s strange that the data coming from each camera looks fine when mapped on a field2d display element and the data coming from our swerve odometry looks fine as well, but the pose estimation is always very strangely not close to any of the input set of values.

Our testing setup is only consisting of the blue side AprilTags for now, so you may see some differences in this code that only apply the the Blue side of the field for now. If we got it working on the Blue side of the field we were going to fix everything else up later on.

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked: 500° seems rather large to be the standard deviation on angle given that the maximum error is 180°.

posts.name: John Fogarty
posts.cooked:
The issue is more the X, Y component being wrong.

I just attempted to make the vision theta std deviation so large that it would not be taken into account.

posts.name: Sean B
posts.cooked: It’s very important set up the offset for all of your cameras (including rotation). The X and Y are dependent on which way the limelight is facing - if the camera is angled 90 degrees for example, it’ll think the robot is facing that way, so X becomes Y and Y becomes X. Just go into the advanced tab where all the 3d targeting stuff is. Put in the translation/rotation of each camera relative to the robot, and then it should work fine.

posts.name: John Fogarty
posts.cooked:
This has already been done.

I think we have an issue with our method of timestamping. I re-read the limelight documentation and what we are doing does not match what they say you should do.

posts.name: Sullivan Dovie
posts.cooked: To test if it’s something with the time stamping, you could remove the timestamp and see if the pose is still incorrect. If the estimated pose seems correct without timestamping while the cameras are not in motion then it’s most likely the problem. For what it’s worth, instead of getting the timestamp from limelight, we get the latency and then calculate the timestamp ourselves with Timer.getFPGATimestamp()-latencyS .

posts.name: Sean B
posts.cooked: Gotcha, I don’t think bad time stamps would cause problems with the coordinates, though. I’ve made that same mistake and it only caused inaccuracy while the robot was moving.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
JohnFogarty:

We set the vision standard deviation to have a really large theta value because of how our limelight mounting strategy works we know the cameras will never correctly report the right angle, but we can be reasonably sure that the Pidgeon 2 on our drive system will be correct.

Why won’t your cameras report the right angle? This seems like something you shouldn’t ignore.

posts.name: John Fogarty
posts.cooked: Because our limelight’s are mounted like this. There’s no value I’ve changed in the Limelight to robot space configuration that makes the camera see the correct robot rotation.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked: If you can’t get the rotation right, how can you expect the X and Y to be right?

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
For this exercise, consider a camera that is pointed straight forward, at the center of your robot.  The camera sees a tag that’s supposed to be at (2, 1) 180-degrees. The LL can estimates that it is 1-meter away and straight on. You can estimate that your pose is (1, 1) 0-degrees from this known tag location. 20230320_151635 1801×2226 193 KB

20230320_151635 1801×2226 193 KB

20230320_151635 1801×2226 193 KB

Now consider the same camera sees the tag, one meter straight ahead but it’s rotated -45-degrees. Your location on the field is not (1, 1) 0-degrees. The robot is at something like (1.3, 0.3) 45-degrees.

20230320_151708 1866×2287 163 KB

20230320_151708 1866×2287 163 KB

20230320_151708 1866×2287 163 KB

This error might be small enough to not matter up close, but as you get far away it will get worse.

posts.name: John Fogarty
posts.cooked:
I see, I didn’t fully understand how the X,Y position was being extrapolated because up close it did appear to be correct. I actually don’t know what distance in this case it would start to become incorrect.

There were two issues. We failed to calculate the required timestamp for the pose estimator. After reviewing the Limelight docs once again we figured out how to do so and immediately saw better results.

I took a look back at the configuration of our camera to robot space in the limelight OS and found that while the camera’s position and orientation within robot looked correct in the 3D field visualizer the data for the robot’s position was wrong. Since we care more about the pose data being returned by the camera being correct than the little robot 3D model we tried inverting the yaw value for our camera mounts from positive 14 degrees to -14 degrees (on one camera, each camera is facing out so the yaw values for each need to be inverted to one another.) and lo and behold the rotation pose being reported by the limelight was now displaying the expected value.

@Brandon_Hjelstrom you may have seen the ping in the FRC discord, but we think this is probably just an issue with the 3D model in the robot->field visualizer’s yaw direction relative to the coordinate system being used. I don’t know if another team using the “bug-eye” mounting approach has reported this as a problem or not.

posts.name: Jackson Elia
posts.cooked: I set the theta standard deviations really high for a different reason, but correct me if you think this is a bad idea: Our gyro only drifts about 1-2 degrees over a full match, so it should probably be accurate enough for everything. What do you think?

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked: It’s probably fine if it’s working. But by really high do you mean like 90-degrees, or 500-degrees? I’m with @bovlb that a standard deviation over 180-degrees doesn’t make a lot of sense.

posts.name: Asher Olgeirson
posts.cooked: I’d check on the limelight web UI that you have the positions of your cameras right. You might want to try inverting the yaw for the camera positions. We had a similar issue with out binocular limelights and that fixed it.

posts.name: Brandon_Hjelstrom
posts.cooked:
@JohnFogarty @Traptricker @Phlogiston @gdefender

2023.5 fixes two major issues:

The “yaw” value in the field space setup section is now internally ccw-positive again. At some point this broke and became cw-positive. This could cause some nasty issues.

The “yaw” value in the field space setup section is now internally ccw-positive again. At some point this broke and became cw-positive. This could cause some nasty issues.

Loading station tags no longer break pose estimation.

Loading station tags no longer break pose estimation.
